item.title: [LOG4J2-3556] JsonTemplateLayout truncation ignores exception cause
item.description:
Stacktrace truncation is helpful to reduce the size of the event, but current approach implemented in LOG4J2-2993 completely removes any "Caused by:" that might be in the stacktrace, while those are the most useful parts of stacktrace.

I'm using the modified EcsLayout.json with suggested truncation point

"error.stack_trace": {
  "$resolver": "exception",
  "field": "stackTrace",
  "stackTrace": {
    "stringified": {
      "truncation": {
        "pointMatcherStrings": ["at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service"],
        "suffix": "\n\t<skipped internal frames>"
      }
    }
  }
}

and the stacktrace I saw on a real production server was rendered as

org.springframework.web.util.NestedServletException: Request processing failed; nested exception is java.lang.NullPointerException
    at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.processRequest(FrameworkServlet.java:1014)
    at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.doPost(FrameworkServlet.java:909)
    at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service
    <skipped internal frames>

which doesn't show anything about origin of the error.

 

The fix should be relatively simple - change StackTraceStringResolver.truncate method to

    private void truncate(
            final TruncatingBufferedPrintWriter writer,
            final int index) {
        int causedByIndex = writer.indexOf("Caused by:");
        CharSequence causedBy = null;
        if (causedByIndex != -1) {
            causedBy = writer.subSequence(causedByIndex - 1, writer.position());
        }
        writer.position(index);
        writer.print(truncationSuffix);
        if (causedByIndex != -1) {
            writer.print(causedBy);
        }
    }

and it correctly displays the stack trace:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: wrapper error
	at reproducer.log4jjsontemplate.StackTraceController.test(StackTraceController.java:18)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:77)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:568)
	at org.springframework.web.method.support.InvocableHandlerMethod.doInvoke(InvocableHandlerMethod.java:205)
	at org.springframework.web.method.support.InvocableHandlerMethod.invokeForRequest(InvocableHandlerMethod.java:150)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.ServletInvocableHandlerMethod.invokeAndHandle(ServletInvocableHandlerMethod.java:117)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.RequestMappingHandlerAdapter.invokeHandlerMethod(RequestMappingHandlerAdapter.java:895)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.RequestMappingHandlerAdapter.handleInternal(RequestMappingHandlerAdapter.java:808)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.AbstractHandlerMethodAdapter.handle(AbstractHandlerMethodAdapter.java:87)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doDispatch(DispatcherServlet.java:1067)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doService(DispatcherServlet.java:963)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.processRequest(FrameworkServlet.java:1006)
	at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.doGet(FrameworkServlet.java:898)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service
	<skipped internal frames>
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: original error
	at reproducer.log4jjsontemplate.StackTraceController.test(StackTraceController.java:16)
	... 50 more

 

I have created an MRE here where you can find more details and monkey patch on a separate branch.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Thanks so much for the report and the detailed description agavlyukovskiy, much appreciated! I see (and agree with) your point regarding losing the most crucial part of the stack trace. Though I think we need something a little bit more sophisticated than that given there might be stack traces whose causal chain is longer than 2. rgrabowski, since you were the one who first asked for this feature, what is your take on this issue?

vy do you mean something like this? I first thought that we might need to process every "Caused by" separately, but JVM does that for me by not rendering matching frames, so finding first "Caused by" seems to be producing desirable stacktrace:

Not sure if there are different cases when you have completely different stacktraces, maybe something like storing exception from one frame and using it as a cause for another exception, or if having multuple pointMatcherStrings/pointMatcherRegexes it might be useful to go over all Caused by stacktraces anyway. I'd be happy to make PR for that if it helps

Maybe the collective "Caused by:" frames are a special case that needs to be recognized with its own truncation policy? That seems to align with Arthur's "multiple pointMatcherStrings/pointMatcherRegexes it might be useful to go over all Caused by stacktraces anyway" comment.

"stackTrace": {
  "stringified": {
    "truncation": {
      "pointMatcherStrings": ["at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service"],
      "suffix": "\n\t<skipped internal frames>"
    },
    "causedByTruncation": {
      "depth": 3
      "pointMatcherStrings": ["at reproducer.log4jjsontemplate"],
      "suffix": "\n\t<skipped internal caused by frames>"
    }
  }
}

causedByTruncation would be applied up to 3 levels down and further layers would be omitted.

Seems like the JVM does a good job being smart with "... 50 more" so causedByDepth could be recognized as an alias for causedByTruncation.depth:

"stackTrace": {
  "stringified": {
    "truncation": {
      "pointMatcherStrings": ["at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service"],
      "suffix": "\n\t<skipped internal frames>"
      "causedByDepth": 2
    }
  }
}

The original intent of the feature was to make an attempt to remove (web) container information. If causedByDepth defaulted to -1 all "Caused by:" would be included which is likely where more meaningful application errors appear.

rgrabowski to your first example: I don't think it would be useful to make distinction between "caused by" frames and main exception frames - if some frames are not important and you want to skip them, then it shouldn't matter where exactly those are located. So I would simplify the configuration to something like this:

"stackTrace": {
  "stringified": {
    "truncation": {
      "pointMatcherStrings": ["at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service", "at reproducer.log4jjsontemplate"],
      "suffix": "\n\t<skipped internal frames>"
    }
  }
}

My point was that if caused by frames have something else we want to skip, then we might need to go over them again, instead of just appending everything starting from the first "Caused by" as I suggested in the description.

Regarding causedByDepth, I think it might be useful as well, though I think it can be quite complicated to set an arbitrary depth, as most important thing is quite often the last one.

The original intent of the feature was to make an attempt to remove (web) container information.

Same for us, we have a limitation on message size in the logging system and truncating all Tomcat logs saves us about 7k characters.

agavlyukovskiy, rgrabowski, thanks so much for the elaborate feedback, much appreciated!

I am inclined to agree with Arthur that we should the split stack trace from caused-by points and exercise find-and-truncate for each chunk. This will require some changes all the way down to TruncatingBufferedWriter. I will add a stackTrace.stringified.truncation.causeSplitEnabled1 property that toggles this behavior. I have started working on this issue, though it won't be simple.

1 I need to admit that I would rather prefer a stackTrace.stringified.truncation.options array where one can provide causeSplit there. This structure is way easier to evolve without introducing any backward compatibility. Yet this makes it impossible to enable this feature by default, hence my preference for the causeSplitEnabled toggle.
Just wanted to share that I am still working on this issue. It exposed a couple more small bugs. I have extended the test suite. I expect to have a working version in 1-2 weeks.
